data.text: A colloidal dispersion of a gas in a liquid or solid medium, such as shaving cream, foam rubber, or a substance used to fight fires. A foam may be produced, especially on the surface of a liquid, by agitation or by a chemical reaction, such as fermentation.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of various light, porous, semirigid or spongy materials, usually the solidified form of a liquid full of gas bubbles, used as a building material or for thermal insulation or shock absorption, as in packaging.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Frothy saliva produced especially as a result of physical exertion or a pathological condition.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The frothy sweat of a horse or other equine animal.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To produce or issue as foam; froth.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To produce foam from the mouth, as from exertion or a pathological condition.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: was foaming over the disastrous budget cuts.
